question_title: Will the Bank of Japan raise its policy interest rate again before May 1, 2026?
summary: The BOJ is on a clear hiking trajectory but the question asks about a narrow window (effectively the March meeting, with the April meeting's inclusion uncertain). The analyst consensus expects the next hike in July 2026, not March. However, hawkish BOJ signals (Ueda calling rates "extremely low," Takata dissenting for an immediate hike, internal views favoring sooner moves) create meaningful upside risk. The spring wage negotiation results (due mid-March) and yen dynamics are key catalysts. Political pressure from PM Takaichi favoring loose policy is a headwind but hasn't stopped the BOJ before (they hiked in December despite her). I estimate ~15-20% probability for a March hike and ~10-15% for an April hike falling within the window, yielding an overall ~35% probability.

factors.description: Analyst consensus (Reuters poll) expects next hike in July, not March or April — only ~25% of analysts see a hike before July
BOJ hawkish signals: Ueda says real rates 'extremely low,' Takata dissented wanting immediate hike to 1%, 'some in BOJ see scope to raise sooner than markets expect'
Rates market started pricing in higher chance of April rate hike after January meeting
Political headwinds: PM Takaichi favors loose monetary policy, snap election Feb 8 — may delay BOJ action
Spring wage negotiations targeting 5%+ for third year — strong results due mid-March could catalyze March hike
Only ~3 months since December 2025 hike — short interval vs historical 4-11 month gaps
Narrow window: effectively only March meeting clearly qualifies; April meeting may or may not fall before May 1 deadline
Persistent inflation above 2% and upgraded GDP growth forecasts support continued normalization
Citigroup sees April hike if yen weakens past 160 — conditional but plausible scenario
